sect1.title: 62 Borrelia*

para.phrase: MARIA E. AGUERO-ROSENFELD AND EVA RUŽIĆ SABLJIĆ

sect1.para: Borrelia species constitute a heterogeneous group of organisms that are maintained in nature in animal reservoirs and are transmitted via arthropod vectors. Most species are restricted to this enzootic cycle, and only a few can cause human disease through the bite of an infected vector. Investigations of Borrelia phylogeny, microbial populations, and their intimate relationship to their arthropod and animal reservoirs have provided insights into their evolution, plasticity, and adaptation to the different ecological niches where they exist (1, 2). New species in vectors and animal reservoirs, as well as new species causing human disease, have been described (3–7).

The complex genomic structure of these organisms allows them to adapt to different environments by expressing different antigens on their surface. Some of these antigens have been associated with virulence and invasion as well as evasion of the host immune system (8).

Borrelia species are agents of relapsing fever (RF), caused by the RF Borrelia group, and Lyme disease (referred to here as Lyme borreliosis [LB]), caused by the LB Borrelia group (9). The latter is the most common vector-borne disease in Europe and the United States and is caused by a group of genetically related species referred to as Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (7, 8). Due to differences in disease associations and biological features in the tick vector, among other characteristics, there have been proposals to separate the RF and LB groups into two genera, but this has created controversies, as discussed below (9). Although B. burgdorferi sensu lato species are found in arthropod vectors in the Southern Hemisphere, Lyme borreliosis has been described only in the Northern Hemisphere. Important aspects of these arthropod-borne diseases are the potential pathogenic properties of the microorganism, the presence of a suitable reservoir, a competent vector(s), and a susceptible human host that becomes a dead-end host. If these factors are not in concert, disease development in humans does not occur.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: Borreliae belong to the orderSpirochaetales, which includes the families Spirochaetaceae and Leptospiraceae. The family Spirochaetaceae includes the genera Borrelia and Treponema. While borreliae are vector borne and cause human disease from a zoonotic source, Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, is acquired from infected humans (10). On the basis of sequence analysis of highly conserved proteins of members of the order Spirochaetales, it was proposed that the genus Borrelia be elevated to the family Borreliaceae (11). Furthermore, Adeolu and Gupta (12) proposed a division of the genus Borrelia into two separate genera: genus Borrelia, containing the causative agents of relapsing fever, and a novel genus, Borreliella gen. nov., containing the causative agents of Lyme borreliosis (12).

Although the proposed division was based on phenotypic and genotypic characteristics, supported by acceptable molecular markers, and encouraged by specific observations regarding specific spirochete-vector-host association and clinical presentation, the proposed separation opened extensive scientific and medical debate (9, 12–15). Available data suggest that millions of years ago, RF Borrelia strains were associated with ancient tick species and were probably symbiotic with primitive ticks. After the Argasidae-Ixodidae tick split, environmental pressures created two Borrelia lineages, one associated with Argasidae (soft ticks) and another associated with Ixodidae (hard ticks). These clades adapted to a tick vector, vertebrate reservoir, and complex lifestyle that is reflected by the modern Borrelia complex genome compositions (7, 9, 13, 15, 16). Similarities and differences between RF and LB Borrelia groups were complicated by the discovery of a third Borrelia lineage described as an intermediate taxon between RF and LB, a reptile- and echidna-associated group (3, 7, 15). Since changes to Borrelia taxonomic nomenclature are still under discussion and not uniformly accepted, we use Borrelia as the genus name for all three groups in this chapter.
The genusBorrelia currently comprises 45 named species, including 21 species within the RF group, 21 within the LB group, and 3 within the third reptile- and echidna-associated group (7, 9).

sect2.para: aAdapted from references 4 and 223.

The RFBorrelia group encompasses species transmitted by different arthropod vectors but predominantly by (argasid) ticks of the genus Ornithodoros. Contrary to LB Borrelia, RF Borrelia species have a wider geographic distribution and cause disease in both hemispheres (Table 1) (4). Members of the LB group of Borrelia share many characteristics but vary in their ability to cause disease and clinical manifestations. Three genospecies of the B. burgdorferi sensu lato complex, B. burgdorferi sensu stricto (referred as B. burgdorferi in this chapter), B. afzelii, and B. garinii, are the species that most frequently cause Lyme borreliosis in the United States and Europe (17, 18). Other genospecies of the B. burgdorferi sensu lato complex that also cause human disease are B. bavariensis, B. bissettiae, B. lusitaniae, B. spielmanii, B. valaisiana, and B. mayonii (19–22). The third Borrelia group, reptile- and echidna-associated Borrelia, has not been described as causing infections in humans (7, 9).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENUS
sect2.para: All borreliae have common characteristics: they are motile spirochetes, helical with pointed ends, 10 to 40 μm in length, and 0.2 to 0.3 μm in diameter (23, 24). As in other spirochetes, an outer membrane surrounds a thin peptidoglycan layer and the cytoplasmic contents are enclosed with an inner membrane. The diderm membrane differs from that of Gram-negative bacteria, particularly in lipopolysaccharide content; the majority of proteins anchored in borrelial outer and inner membranes are lipoproteins. Lipoproteins from the inner membrane are in close association with the peptidoglycan layer, while those on the outer membrane are surface exposed (23). As described below, many of these surface proteins are involved in host-pathogen interactions. Flagella are located in the periplasmic space, between the inner and outer membrane, and are attached at opposite poles of the cell at one end and overlap in the center. They are wrapped around the protoplasmic cylinder and are responsible for typical spirochete rotational motion and flexing (23, 24). Borrelia species are microaerophilic with very limited metabolic capacity and metabolize carbohydrates or amino acids as carbon and energy sources. They divide by transverse binary fission (11, 13, 23).

sect1.title: Genomes
sect1.para: A hallmark ofBorrelia species is a segmented genome consisting of a linear chromosome and a mix of linear and circular plasmids. The linear DNA genome structure found in the Borrelia genus is uncommon in bacteria (7, 13, 16, 25–28). Their G+C content is 27 to 32 mol% (25). Data suggest that all three Borrelia groups (RF, LB, and reptile and echidna associated) have genomes of similar sizes, about 1.5 Mb. Strains from particular groups differ in plasmid number per cell as well as plasmid molecular masses (26, 29, 30). Among all sequenced Borrelia strains, those within the LB group harbor the largest number of plasmids reported in any bacterial species; strain B31 has up to 12 linear plasmids and 11 circular plasmids with molecular masses of 5 to 84 kb. RF Borrelia group strains harbor smaller numbers of plasmids, with molecular masses ranging from 5 to 165 kb; e.g., B. recurrentis (A1 strain) has only 7 linear plasmids, while B. duttonii (Ly strain) has 15 linear plasmids and 1 circular plasmid. Comparison of the genomes of these two RF Borrelia strains reveals that their chromosomes are colinear and that, although reduced in number, all B. recurrentis plasmids have a counterpart in B. duttonii. It is postulated that because of genome similarities, B. recurrentis is a strain of B. duttonii and that the loss of genetic material in the former might be related to its increased virulence (31). Furthermore, comparison of RF Borrelia genomes by sequence analysis revealed B. recurrentis, B. duttonii, and B. crocidurae to be closely related but unique genospecies, as seems to be the case for North American B. hermsii and B. parkeri. Further work on complete genome sequencing will likely clarify the taxonomy of these organisms (4, 12, 32). Members of the reptile- and echidna-associated Borrelia group (A-FGy1 isolate) harbor plasmids from 30 to 130 kb in size (3).

Contrary to the requirements of most bacteria, plasmids are essential forBorrelia. While the Borrelia chromosome contains genes that predominantly encode proteins for housekeeping functions with very limited metabolic capacity, genes encoding proteins with functions needed for arthropod vector and vertebrate host interactions, as well as for adaptation and invasion, are located in plasmids. This is why linear plasmids also are referred to as minichromosomes (26, 29).

Chromosomal sequence homology is quite conserved among the differentB. burgdorferi sensu lato species sequenced, except at one end of the linear chromosome, where there are plasmid-like sequences. However, there are differences among the different B. burgdorferi sensu lato species in the number of plasmids present as well as in the genetic traits encoded by them. Among plasmids, linear plasmid 54 (lp54), circular plasmid 26 (cp26), and cp32 are found in all B. burgdorferi sensu lato species sequenced (16). Many genes on these plasmids are essential for interactions with arthropod vectors and for virulence in animal hosts (33). Plasmid lp54 encodes outer surface proteins OspA and -B, important in the tick environment, as well as decorin-binding proteins DbpA and -B, important in host interactions (26, 27). OspC, which is upregulated during tick feeding, is encoded on cp26. Analysis of OspC sequences from different strains suggests that gene exchange might be important for antigenic diversity and immune evasion (34). Analysis of the plasmids reveals that they contain pseudogenes and genes in evolutionary decay, some with prophage-like sequences that would allow recombination and DNA rearrangement (26, 27). Plasmid lp28-1 contains a contiguous set of 15 silent gene cassettes in the variable major protein-like sequence (vls) locus. Small stretches of genetic material from these silent cassettes are transferred to an expression site, vlsE, located on the same plasmid. This generates a mosaic vlsE gene that allows continuous modification and antigenic diversity of the VlsE (variable major protein-like sequences expressed) outer surface lipoprotein needed for pathogen-host interaction (35), allowing the pathogen to remain one step ahead of the acquired immune response and enabling persistent infection (16, 35).

The linear plasmids ofB. hermsii and B. turicatae contain genes encoding outer membrane lipoproteins, called variable major proteins (VMPs). As seen in LB Borrelia, these genes are silent except when they are translocated to an expression site immediately adjacent to one of the linear plasmid telomeres, as described for VlsE (16, 35).

sect1.title: Relapsing Fever Borrelia Group
sect1.para: AlthoughB. anserina, described in 1891, is the prototype of Borrelia species, it does not cause illness in humans. B. anserina found its host in birds, is transmitted by Argas sp. soft ticks, and is distributed worldwide (4). Other RF species are transmitted by Ornithodoros tick spp. or Ixodes spp. (B. miyamotoi). Based on DNA sequence analysis, there are currently 21 published species within the RF group (Table 1). The current systematic approach regarding the RF Borrelia sp. reflects vector-Borrelia-host associations and geographic distributions of species and recognizes four groups (4, 32).

listitem.para: B. recurrentis is the only RF species distributed worldwide and transmitted by the louse Pediculus humanus. Undoubtedly, it is the Borrelia species that caused the most epidemics in the past. Although personal hygiene and sanitary conditions have improved, there are still cases in impoverished areas of the world and places where individuals from these areas have emigrated (4, 36–38).

The Old World RFBorrelia species, such as B. duttonii, B. crocidurae, B. caucasica, B. persica, etc., are distributed in Africa, the Middle East, the Mediterranean, Central Asia, and India and are transmitted by Ornithodoros ticks (4, 39).

The New World RFBorrelia species, such as B. hermsii, B. coriaceae, B. parkeri, B. turicatae, etc., are distributed in North, Central, and South America and are also transmitted by Ornithodoros ticks.

The ixodid-borneBorrelia sp. B. miyamotoi is found in the Northern Hemisphere (Asia, Europe, and North America). B. miyamotoi was first isolated from Ixodes persulcatus in Japan in the mid-1990s (40). Since then, it has been found to cause human disease in Russia and subsequently in North America, Europe, and Japan. In North America and Europe, it is transmitted by I. scapularis and I. ricinus, respectively (5, 41–44). Other non-human-infective Borrelia species present in ixodid ticks are B. lonestari, transmitted by Amblyomma americanum in North America, and B. theileri, transmitted by Rhipicephalus spp. in North and South America, Africa, and Australia (4, 45).

sect1.para: The characteristic presentation of RF infection correlates with the appearance of new immunogenic variants of their outer membrane lipoprotein, called VMPs. Genes encoding VMPs make up two distinct multigene families:vlp genes, encoding variable large proteins, and vsp genes, encoding variable small proteins. Genes of both families are located on linear plasmids. Genetic variation involved in VMP shifting results either from random fixation via genetic drift or from vlp and vsp polymorphisms selected by the host immune system (4, 8, 46).

sect1.title: LB Borrelia Group
sect1.para: Over 20 genospecies ofB. burgdorferi sensu lato complex are transmitted by ixodid ticks of the genus Ixodes, but only a few of these species cause Lyme borreliosis in humans (1, 9) (Table 1). Among them, B. burgdorferi and, in a very few cases, B. mayonii have been found to cause infection in North America (6, 17, 47). In Europe, B. afzelii is the dominant human pathogen, followed by B. garinii, B. burgdorferi, B. bavariensis, and B. spielmanii. Less frequently, B. bissettiae, B. valaisiana, and B. lusitaniae can cause human infection (48–50). B. bavariensis, which utilizes rodents as reservoir hosts, was raised to species level in 2009 after having been included in the species B. garinii; the latter species utilizes birds as reservoir hosts (20). Both these species and B. afzelii are also present across Eurasia, but in Asia they have adapted to different Ixodes vectors (20, 51, 52). In addition to the species that cause disease in humans, there are other species found in ticks and reservoir hosts from different geographic areas that are nonpathogenic for humans. These include B. americana, B. andersonii, B. bissettiae, B. californiensis, B. carolinensis, B. kurtenbachii, B. lanei, and B. maritima in North America, B. finlandensis in Europe, and B. japonica, B. sinica, B. tanukii, B. turdi, and B. yangtzensis in Asia (53). In addition, B. chilensis, a new Borrelia species genetically distinct from other LB group species, was found in South America (54).

Although members of LB group ofBorrelia have similar characteristics, they vary in their ability to cause disease in humans as well as in clinical manifestations. Their obligate parasitism makes their biology intimately related to the arthropod vector and animal host reservoir where they reside (8).

sect1.title: Relapsing Fever Borrelia Group
sect1.para: Relapsing feverBorrelia exist in many different geographic areas worldwide. They are mostly transmitted by soft and hard-bodied ticks, therefore the disease they cause is known as Tick-borne Relapsing Fever (TBRF). Most species causing TBRF are transmitted by Argasid soft-bodied ticks in the genus Ornithodoros (55). These ticks take blood meals at night and feed rapidly; they do not remain attached to the host for prolonged intervals (56, 57). The main characteristic of Ornithodoros ticks is their longevity, up to 7 years for Ornithodoros turicata and 5 to 10 years for O. tholozani, while the spirochetes harbored by this tick remain viable over a 5-year period of tick starvation (58). Once Ornithodoros ticks are infected, they remain infectious for life, and because of vertical transovarian transmission, the progeny emerge infected. Thus, these ticks not only are vectors but also serve as reservoirs for RF Borrelia. They also have several nymph stages, and females feed several times to complete a life cycle that might take many years. In addition, RF Borrelia spp. are located in the tick salivary gland at the onset of feeding; therefore, transmission can occur rapidly after tick attachment. Reservoirs include wild rodents, insectivores, foxes, domestic animals, and other mammals, particularly chipmunks (Tamias spp.) and squirrels (Tamiasciurus spp.) in North America, and particularly rodents of the genera Mastomys and Praomys and shrews (Crocidura olivieri in West and North Africa) (57, 59). Birds and bats are also reservoirs; their major role might be to disperse ticks and their spirochetes over wider geographic areas. Ornithodoros ticks typically live close to their hosts, in their nests and burrows, allowing them a secure food source. Human infection usually occurs in regions of endemicity where humans are in close proximity to rodents and ticks, in mountain cabins, man-made shelters, caves, and ruins or when camping or sleeping outdoors (57, 60). In East Africa, typical traditional dwellings known as tembes, as well as burrows in West and North Africa, can be heavily infested with Ornithodoros ticks (32, 59).

In the western United States, the disease typically occurs in forests at high elevation whereO. hermsii ticks live, frequently caused by B. hermsii (57). O. turicata prefers lower elevation and drier habitats and transmits B. turicata, which parasitizes numerous free-living animals but also dogs, pigs, and cattle. B. parkeri, which is rarely associated with human infection, is transmitted by O. parkeri, found in the western United States (57). Tick-borne RF (TBRF) is reportable in 12 states in the United States, and most reported cases are from California, Washington, and Colorado. A total of 504 cases were reported between 1990 and 2011; the median number was 20 per year (60). The largest outbreak occurred in Arizona in 1973, when 62 persons acquired the disease near the Grand Canyon. Other reports from Arizona include an outbreak among high school football team members who acquired tick bites, and subsequently TBRF, while cleaning cabins in preparation for a youth event (61, 62), and cases in the White Mountains near Phoenix and Tucson (63). All were caused by B. hermsii. TBRF caused by B. turicatae is described; two patients were infected in the Mojave Desert, Nevada, in association with excavation in areas of tortoise burrows (64). An additional case due to B. turicatae was reported from Austin, Texas (65).

In Europe, tick-borne RF occurs in the Mediterranean regions of Spain, Portugal, Greece, and Cyprus.B. hispanica is responsible for the majority of cases and is transmitted by O. erraticus ticks, which are predominant in this region (55). Relapsing fever is rare in Europe; many cases are imported by patients traveling from regions of endemicity. Recently, European physicians reported imported cases related to refugees from parts of Africa where RF is endemic, making the clinical distinction of tick- and louse-borne RF difficult, because both are present in these African countries (33, 55, 59, 66, 67).

In North Africa and northwestern Africa, from Egypt to Senegal, the dominant RFBorrelia species is B. crocidurae, which is transmitted by the tick O. sonrai. In certain regions, B. crocidurae coexists with B. hispanica (Morocco and Tunisia) as well as with B. merionesi (Morocco and Western Sahara), but the latter two species are transmitted by a different Ornithodoros sp. tick (4, 55, 59). In eastern, central, and southern Africa, B. duttonii, transmitted by O. moubata ticks, coexists with B. recurrentis, transmitted by the human body louse, Pediculus humanus. Furthermore, in northern Africa, B. duttonii coexists with B. crocidurae. B. crocidurae, B. duttonii, and B. recurrentis share 99% identity, suggesting that they are derived from one species that adapted to different vectors. Moreover, humans are the only reservoirs for B. recurrentis and B. duttonii (4, 31, 55, 68). Tick-borne RF is usually associated with rural locations, agricultural work, infested houses, and crowded populations. It remains endemic in West, South, and East African regions and is reported as the most common bacterial infection in Senegal despite many cases being classified as malaria on clinical grounds. RF remains a significant cause of mortality and morbidity in Tanzania, where it is associated with pregnancy loss or premature deliveries in pregnant women and is usually listed among the top 10 causes of mortality in children under 5 years. The incidence of RF in North Africa seems to be much lower than the incidence in West Africa, probably because of better quality of housing (4, 58, 68, 69).

TBRF in Eurasia is mainly attributed toB. persica, although other Borrelia species are described. O. tholozani is the most important tick vector for TBRF in Eurasia and can be found in India and Kashmir, the southern countries of the former Soviet Union, Iran, Iraq, Syria, Jordan, Turkey, Israel, Egypt, and Cyprus. A majority of cases are related to outbreaks in young people, military personnel, herdsmen, tourists, and researchers who have entered caves or bunkers without personal protective measures. As in Mediterranean countries, relapsing fever is rare in Eurasia (58, 70).

While most RFBorrelia spp. are transmitted by argasid ticks, a few species are transmitted by ixodid ticks. These include B. miyamotoi, transmitted by Ixodes spp., and B. turcica, otherwise associated with reptile reservoirs and not yet described in humans, which is transmitted by Hyalomma aegyptium (71, 72). B. miyamotoi has been found in ticks in Japan through Russia (mostly in I. persulcatus), in Eurasia (I. persulcatus and I. ricinus), in European countries (I. ricinus), and in North America (I. scapularis and I. pacificus), but at low infection rates (5, 73, 74). Although B. miyamotoi and LB Borrelia species share the same animal reservoir and vector, the former can be present in larvae due to transovarial transmission in the tick vector (4, 71).

The proportion ofIxodes ticks carrying B. miyamotoi varies across the United States. While B. burgdorferi predominates over B. miyamotoi in I. scapularis in the Northeast, the opposite is true in I. pacificus on the West Coast (71).

B. recurrentis is transmitted by the human body louse, Pediculus humanus, and is restricted to areas where clothing lice persist. With the reduction of the vector P. humanus, and due to improved living standards and insecticide introduction, infection declined and finally disappeared from most parts of the world. Therefore, although it was once prevalent throughout the world and a cause of epidemics, it is now mostly endemic to sub-Saharan Africa, especially Tanzania, Ethiopia, and Sudan, where poverty and crowded living conditions exist. In these areas, B. recurrentis coexists with the closely related species B. duttonii and B. crocidurae (4, 36, 58, 68). Nevertheless, louse-borne RF Borrelia (LBRF) is observed in Europe among African refugees, and local transmission is reported. The refugee crisis, with thousands of people from areas of endemicity arriving in Europe and living in precarious conditions, led to an increase of LBRF cases. In 2015, 28 cases among African refugees were reported from different European countries; the majority were reported in Germany (38, 75). A study conducted among 930 homeless people during a 4-year period in Marseilles, France, found that 15/930 (1.6%) had antibodies to B. recurrentis compared to 0/467 controls (76).

sect1.title: B. burgdorferi sensu lato (LB Borrelia Group)
sect1.para: B. burgdorferi sensu lato species cause LB, the most common vector-borne disease in the Northern Hemisphere (47, 77). It is estimated that over 300,000 cases occur annually in the United States (47), although the annual reportable incidence was 10.69/100,000 population in 2019 (78). Most cases in the United States are reported from Northeast, Mid-Atlantic, and Upper Midwest states (77). The incidence of Lyme borreliosis in Europe ranges from 0.7/100,000 in the United Kingdom to >300/100,000 in Slovenia (19). On the basis of data from Germany, with a population of about 82 million inhabitants, a number of annual Lyme borreliosis cases of about 215,000 can be extrapolated (79).

These organisms are transmitted by ticks in theI. ricinus complex, and rodents are the primary reservoir (Table 1). B. garinii uses birds as a reservoir (20). In the northeastern and upper midwestern United States, the vector is I. scapularis, while I. pacificus is the vector in the western United States. In Europe, the tick vector is I. ricinus, and in Asia, it is I. persulcatus.

I. ricinus complex ticks usually have a 2-year life span and obtain three blood meals over that span, as larvae, nymphs, and adult females. While larvae prefer to obtain a meal from small mammals and birds, nymphs and adults prefer larger mammals, including humans. At each blood meal, the tick can acquire B. burgdorferi sensu lato from an infected animal reservoir (47). In most European regions where Lyme borreliosis is endemic, the average infection rates of I. ricinus ticks range between 10 and 30% (80–82). Transovarial transmission has not been confirmed as documented for RF Borrelia. B. burgdorferi sensu lato species colonize the midgut of the infected tick, and efficient transmission of the pathogen to a susceptible human requires prolonged feeding over 24 to 48 h. Therefore, prompt removal of an attached tick is an efficient method to prevent Lyme borreliosis (47). B. burgdorferi is the most common species causing Lyme borreliosis in the northeast, mid-Atlantic, and upper midwestern United States. A few cases associated with B. bissettiae have been described in the southeastern and West Coast regions of the United States (21). In 2016, a novel species of the B. burgdorferi sensu lato group was described in the midwestern United States. This species, named B. mayonii due to its identification at the Mayo Clinic, has been found only in the upper midwestern United States (83). It is also transmitted by I. scapularis, and its reservoir also includes rodents. In contrast to other Borrelia spp. that cause LB, spirochetemia can reach detectable microscopic levels with B. mayonii (6).

Lyme borreliosis in Europe and Asia is caused byB. burgdorferi sensu lato genospecies with greater heterogeneity (84, 85) than those that cause disease in the United States. This leads to different clinical manifestations associated with different species in Europe (B. afzelii, B. garinii, B. bavariensis, B. burgdorferi sensu stricto, and B. spielmanii). The main species causing skin infections is B. afzelii (80 to 90%), while up to 70% of neurological disorders with LB in Europe are caused by B. garinii (including B. bavariensis). B. burgdorferi sensu stricto is rarely reported in European patients (18). Original studies in Europe found differences sufficient to define at least eight OspA serotypes (86), which correlate closely with genetic classification of the species. This complex serotyping method has been replaced by genotyping that more simply delineates human pathogen species and other species from B. burgdorferi sensu lato complex found in ticks and reservoir hosts (87). B. afzelii and B. garinii are distributed all over Eurasia, while B. burgdorferi sensu stricto is restricted to European countries (18). Comparative studies on European and North American B. burgdorferi sensu stricto strains revealed that they vary in virulence, inflammatory potential, and clinical manifestations and that European B. burgdorferi sensu stricto strains share similar characteristics with the other species causing LB in Europe (88).

sect1.title: Relapsing Fever Borrelia Group
sect1.para: Relapsing fever caused by RFBorrelia is characterized by recurring spirochetemia associated with recurrent episodes of high fever. The recurrence of spirochetemia and associated clinical findings are related to the development of antibodies to Borrelia VMPs, leading to a reduction of organisms in circulation. When spirochetes are eliminated from the blood, they survive in extravascular sites, tissue and organs. Borrelia organisms with altered expression of VMP surface antigens evade newly developed antibodies, leading to rebound bacteremia (55, 57, 60). This can occur several times, leading to the relapsing presentation. Up to 13 recurrences of fever in untreated patients with TBRF have been reported (4, 57, 68, 89).

Individual variability in clinical presentation is frequent. In addition to fever, patients might experience headaches, myalgia, and arthralgia; some may present as having meningitis, flu-like illness, or gastrointestinal illness. One common laboratory abnormality is thrombocytopenia. LBRF can present with hemorrhagic diathesis and have a higher lethality than TBRF, which has an estimated case fatality rate of 2 to 5% (37, 90); myocarditis has been prominent in fatal cases (36, 37, 68, 89). Since RF Borrelia organisms coexist with other pathogens in areas of Africa where they are endemic, it is likely that coinfections exist more frequently than they are documented. Simultaneous malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum and RF caused by B. crocidurae have been reported in patients in Senegal (91).

Infection withB. miyamotoi, first described in Russian patients in 2011, commonly presented as acute febrile illness with high fever (40°C), lasting less than a week and accompanied by headache, myalgia, arthralgia, and chills. Patients experienced a maximum of three febrile episodes. Although clinical presentations of RF caused by B. miyamotoi and other RF borreliae are similar, the latter can present with more febrile episodes and longer duration (4, 5, 57, 68, 71). Although earlier reports described B. miyamotoi infection associated with central nervous system disorders in immunocompromised individuals, it has also been described in immunocompetent individuals (92). Some differences in B. miyamotoi infection occurring in different geographic areas include the presence of thrombocytopenia and leukopenia, seen in U.S. patients but not in European or Asian patients (44, 74, 93). Differences in clinical presentation of patients infected with B. miyamotoi in the United States and Eurasia appear to indicate that they may be related to genetic and antigenic differences between strains (5). B. miyamotoi sensu stricto has been proposed as the name for strains found in Asia and B. miyamotoi sensu lato for those in North America (28).

A skin lesion designated STARI (southern tick-associated rash illness), sometimes confused with erythema migrans (EM), has been described in patients from the southern United States. This skin rash is associated with the bite ofA. americanum, and its infectious etiology, if any, is currently unknown. It was once thought to be caused by B. lonestari, but this is currently disputed (45, 94).

sect1.title: Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (LB Borrelia Group)
sect1.para: The hallmark of early Lyme borreliosis is the development of an expanding erythematous skin lesion at the site of the tick bite, known as EM (17, 18) (Table 2). Because it happens soon after the tick bite, EM is observed primarily in the spring and summer, when ticks are actively biting. The diagnosis of early Lyme borreliosis with EM is clinical and relies on the presence of the characteristic skin lesion in individuals living in areas of endemicity who are exposed to Ixodes tick bites (95). EM often occurs alone, but it can be accompanied by fever, fatigue, headache, mild stiff neck, arthralgia, or myalgia. European early Lyme borreliosis with EM is less frequently accompanied by constitutional symptoms than that in the United States (19, 96, 97).

If untreated, the infection can disseminate mainly by hematogenous spread but also via peripheral nerves (98), leading to manifestations of early disseminated infection within days or weeks of the initial EM. Different levels of spirochetemia between U.S. and European patients have also been documented (99). Early dissemination leads to infection at other skin sites with multiple EM lesions, neurologic manifestations (meningitis, cranial nerve palsies, and meningoradiculoneuritis, seen in Europe and known as Bannwarth syndrome) (100), or cardiac involvement (myocarditis and atrioventricular block) (17, 18). Dissemination is associated with specific antigenic and molecular characteristics of B. burgdorferi (101). In Europe, multiple EM lesions are seen more frequently in children (102, 103).

Late complications of Lyme borreliosis also differ between the United States and Europe. In the United States, the most common manifestation is intermittent or persistent mono- or oligoarthritis that develops in months to a few years after infection (17). Arthritis also occurs in European patients; however, spontaneous remission of arthritis is frequent and transition to chronic manifestations is rather rare (104).

Acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans (ACA) is a common late manifestation of Lyme borreliosis in Europe. ACA starts as a skin infiltration that occurs after a long incubation period (months to years), followed by characteristic atrophic changes of the skin, which appears pleated, like shriveled tissue paper, with livid discoloration and prominent veins. It usually starts on one extremity, often the extensor side, but may become symmetrical over time (18). In contrast to EM and borrelial lymphocytoma, ACA does not heal spontaneously.

Rarely, late Lyme borreliosis might present with neurological manifestations such as encephalopathy or encephalomyelitis. Lyme encephalopathy is seldom encountered now; it was originally described in patients with long-standing Lyme borreliosis with arthritis. This entity consists of difficulties with memory, cognition, and intellectual function (105). These manifestations are nonspecific to Lyme borreliosis and might be observed in association with inflammatory or other infectious diseases (106).

WhileB. burgdorferi in the United States causes mostly EM in early infection and arthritis as a late manifestation, there are other important species-specific manifestations or associations. B. afzelii, the most common cause of Lyme borreliosis in Europe, causes EM in early stages and ACA as a late manifestation (17, 18) (Table 2). B. garini and B. bavariensis are associated with Lyme neuroborreliosis. Lyme neuroborreliosis is frequently manifested by the involvement of cranial and/or peripheral nerves associated with lymphocytic meningitis. Typical manifestation in adult European patients with neuroborreliosis is Bannwarth syndrome, which is extremely rare in North American patients (107). B. burgdorferi sensu stricto infection in Europe, although rare, is associated with clinical mani-festations similar to those caused by other European species and not with arthritis, as is characteristic in North America (88). Lyme carditis is reported in approximately 1% of U.S. and European patients. Other differences between Lyme borreliosis occurring in the United States and Europe include more frequent central clearing of EM in Europe, presence of systemic symptoms in patients with early disease in the United States, development of borrelial lymphocytoma in European patients, and significantly more asymptomatic infection in European than North American patients (97). Based on LB borrelia seroprevalence among hunters in Europe, who rarely recall a history of clinical Lyme borreliosis, it is likely that many individuals experience asymptomatic infections (108). It is not known if these asymptomatic infections are species specific.

The existence of “chronic” Lyme borreliosis, in which the organism persists despite a course of conventional antibiotic therapy, is not supported by extensive microbiological, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical studies (109, 110). This diagnosis has been used to explain nonspecific symptoms such as myalgias, arthralgias, and concentration problems in individuals in whom no objective evidence of ongoing B. burgdorferi infection can be documented (111).

B. mayonii, described in 2016 in patients from the upper Midwest of the United States, has a different clinical picture than the other members of the Lyme borreliosis group. Of the six cases originally described, most presented with a febrile illness and maculopapular skin rash. Most striking was the presence of detectable spirochetemia on peripheral blood smears, documented by quantitative PCR tests, which is not seen in Lyme borreliosis caused by other genospecies of B. burgdorferi sensu lato (6).

sect2.title: Relapsing Fever Borrelia Group
sect2.para: RFBorrelia can be detected in peripheral blood with blood films prepared from blood collected with EDTA. This specimen can also be used for PCR and culture. Occasionally, other samples, such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), have been useful in cases of B. miyamotoi infection with meningoencephalitis.
Blood for serum preparation should also be collected during the acute and convalescent phases forBorrelia serology.

sect2.title: Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (LB Borrelia Group)
sect2.para: For culture and nucleic acid detection ofBorrelia, collection and preparation of specimens under sterile conditions are of utmost importance. Body fluids should be transported without any additives, and biopsy specimens should be placed in a small quantity of sterile saline or suitable culture medium (see “Culture” below). Samples should reach the laboratory as quickly as possible, ideally within 2 to 4 h. Culture is rarely performed in clinical laboratories in regions of endemicity but is available in some public health and research laboratories.

Skin biopsy samples of EM, ACA, or borrelial lymphocytoma cutis lesions can be used for culture or nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) such as PCR. Nevertheless, culture and PCR of EM lesions have mostly been utilized in research settings, since laboratory testing is not required to establish the diagnosis at this early stage (112, 113). Prompt inoculation of biopsy samples into medium has led to successful culture of B. burgdorferi in research settings (our unpublished experience).

Whole blood collected in EDTA can be used to perform culture or PCR during the early disseminated phase of the disease. As for standard bacterial blood culture methods, large volumes of blood (9 ml of plasma) have been used to more effectively isolateB. burgdorferi sensu lato in culture (114). It has been reported that blood collected in citrate anticoagulant might be superior to EDTA to recover B. burgdorferi in culture (115).

Serum should be collected in the acute and convalescence phases, separated by at least 2 weeks, to detect the presence of diagnostic antibodies in serum, the most common means to support the clinical diagnosis (112).

Cerebrospinal fluid collected in patients with neurological manifestations might be of utility to detectB. burgdorferi sensu lato in culture or by PCR, although the sensitivity of such testing is low, as discussed below. As indicated above, prompt delivery of samples to the laboratory and prompt inoculation into media improve the recovery in culture in research settings.

CSF and serum should be collected simultaneously to test for the production of intrathecal antibodies expressed in a CSF/serum antibody index (112, 113). However, although this method is more frequently used in Europe, it is offered by very few laboratories in the United States (116).

Synovial fluid or tissue is useful for diagnosing patients suspected of having Lyme arthritis and for monitoring treatment efficacy. These can be tested by PCR or, less often, by culture, a method restricted to research settings.

sect2.title: Relapsing Fever Borrelia Group
sect2.para: Most RFBorrelia organisms can be present at high levels in blood, exceeding 106 organisms/ml. This feature allows their detection in routine blood smears stained with Wright-Giemsa stain (57, 117) (Fig. 1). Microscopic detection has also been achieved in cerebrospinal fluid of patients infected with B. miyamotoi who experience meningoencephalitis.

Other microscopic preparations used for the diagnosis of RF infection include thick smear preparations, such as those used for malaria screening, wet mounts to detect motile spirochetes with dark-field microscopy, and the quantitative buffy coat (QBC) method, which is commonly used to detect malaria parasites (118). The sensitivities of these methods have been estimated at 25% for routine blood smear examination (detecting spirochetemia of at least 105/ml) and 50 to 70% for the thick smear (sensitivity of approximately 104 spirochetes/ml), and QBC has a better sensitivity, detecting spirochetes at about 103/ml (118).

sect1.title: Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (LB Borrelia Group)
sect1.para: Lyme borreliosis with EM is a clinical diagnosis. However, laboratory evidence of infection is needed for patients with all manifestations except for typical EM (95, 112, 113) (Table 2).

sect1.para: Microscopy can be used to visualizeB. burgdorferi sensu lato in skin biopsy samples from patients with EM or ACA with special stains, such as silver stains (112, 119). Nevertheless, this method is infrequently used for diagnostic purposes due to low spirochete density. Unlike other LB Borrelia spp., B. mayonii has been visualized on peripheral blood smears. One of the six patients diagnosed with B. mayonii infection had microscopically detectable spirochetemia of around 8.5 × 104/ml; on the basis of quantitative PCR, it was estimated that all cases had a median of 8.1 × 105 organisms per ml, within the range of microscopic detection. In contrast to B. mayonii patients, 12 patients for whom PCR was positive for B. burgdorferi in blood had a median level of spirochetes of 4.5 × 103/ml, making B. burgdorferi less likely to be detected by microscopy of peripheral blood smears (6).

sect1.title: Relapsing Fever Borrelia Group
sect1.para: RFBorrelia can be cultured in Barbour-Stoenner-Kelly (BSK) medium by specialized or research laboratories (117, 120). The formulation of the medium used at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Division of Vector-Borne Diseases Branch, Fort Collins, CO) is BSK-II medium supplemented with 12% young rabbit serum. Variations of the original Kelly medium, such as BSK-II, BSK-H, and modified Kelly-Pettenkofer (MKP) media, also support growth of RF Borrelia species, including B. miyamotoi (61, 68, 118, 121). Members of the RF Borrelia group are more diverse in their requirements for cultivation than the LB group, and some are difficult to culture. Special attention to culture B. miyamotoi in the last few years has resulted in improvements in its yield, particularly with the addition of fetal calf serum (122, 123). A 50-μl blood sample collected in an EDTA tube is inoculated into a 5-ml polypropylene tube filled with 4.5 ml of BSK-II medium and incubated at 34°C. Cultures are microscopically examined at different time points for the presence of Borrelia (61). A 300-μl blood sample collected without anticoagulant, inoculated in 7-ml tubes with MKP, and incubated at 33°C successfully supported RF Borrelia isolation (118). In a facility in Africa with restricted laboratory equipment, RF Borrelia was isolated from blood samples collected without anticoagulant, directly inoculated into BSK-II medium, and incubated at room temperature (124).

Modified Kelly medium containing 5% heat-inactivated rabbit serum, bovine serum albumin, and gelatin was used successfully to recoverB. crocidurae from the blood of patients in West Africa (118). RF Borrelia might take 2 to 10 days of incubation to be detected in culture. Once the cultures have been confirmed as positive, samples of the culture can be subjected to NAATs and sequencing to identify the species (118).

Since some RFBorrelia species might have a low level of spirochetemia and laboratory confirmation is challenging, animal inoculation has been used as an alternative method. In this method, 250 μl of patient blood is injected intraperitoneally into mice, and the mouse blood is examined microscopically at various intervals or after animal exsanguination (117, 120). Although not widely used for diagnostic purposes, animal inoculation has been employed in research settings and was successfully used in the investigation of TBRF outbreaks in California (120) and in European patients returning from Africa (117, 118, 120, 121).

sect1.title: Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (LB Borrelia Group)
sect1.para: B. burgdorferi sensu lato can be cultured in vitro in liquid BSK, MKP, and variations of these media under microaerophilic conditions (114, 125–127). The optimum growth temperature for B. burgdorferi sensu lato is 30 to 34°C; cultures are incubated for 9 to 12 weeks before negativity is reported. On average, positive results may be observed after 2 to 3 weeks of incubation, but occasionally borreliae may be observed by dark-field microscopy after 4 days, particularly with skin biopsy samples. For species differentiation of isolated strains, several molecular genetic methods have been used (128, 129).

B. burgdorferi sensu lato has been cultured in 40 to 88% of skin biopsy samples of patients with EM (112, 130), in about 30% of samples from those with ACA (131), and in about 33% of borrelial lymphocytoma samples from European patients (132).

The organism has also been cultured from whole blood, serum, and plasma in 5 to 70.8% of samples collected from patients with early Lyme borreliosis (114, 133, 134). Better yield of blood culture has been achieved by culturing blood volumes similar to those used in routine bacterial blood cultures (114). A modification of blood culture that has given a higher rate of positivity in patients with early Lyme borreliosis and EM is the combination of culturing 9 ml of plasma with periodic testing of culture aliquots by quantitative PCR. With this approach, 45 of 65 (70.8%) patients with clinical diagnosis of EM had a positive result (133).

In Europe (Slovenia),B. burgdorferi sensu lato was cultured from CSF in 12/77 (15.6%) patients with Bannwarth syndrome; 11 CSF isolates were identified as B. garinii and one as B. afzelii (107). In 7/51 (13.7%) Slovenian children with acute peripheral facial palsy, Borrelia was isolated from CSF; B. garinii was the only identified species in these patients (135). Another European study reported its isolation in CSF culture from three of eight children with Lyme neuroborreliosis (136). Unpublished experience supports the use of at least 2 ml of CSF into culture medium for better results.
B. burgdorferi has been infrequently isolated from other sample types. The rate of recovery of B. burgdorferi sensu lato from synovial tissue or fluid by culture is extremely low.

sect1.title: Relapsing Fever Borrelia Group
sect1.para: Compared with microscopic detection, NAATs are more sensitive and can be used for species identification. Various genes, such as those encoding 16S rRNA (rrs), flagellin, and glycerophosphodiester phosphodiesterase (glpQ), and the 16S-23S rRNA intergenic spacer region and others have been targeted, often in combination (36, 61, 117, 118, 121, 124, 137).

BecauseBorrelia spp. are closely related at the molecular level, analysis of 16S rRNA (rrs) gene sequences may not offer good discrimination between species (137). For example, there is only one nucleotide difference in rrs between B. crocidurae and B. duttonii (137). Other sequences that can be used for species identification include flaB and the 16S-23S rRNA intergenic spacer gene, especially when used in multispacer sequence typing or multilocus sequence typing (MLST) (61, 117, 137, 138).

NAAT of the 16S rRNA gene followed by nested PCR of the 16S-23S intergenic spacer gene and sequencing on positive samples was used in an outbreak due toB. hermsii in the United States to detect RF Borrelia in patient samples and ticks (61). The same approach was also successfully applied in European patients (118, 121).

Several studies have been conducted utilizing multiplex PCR that allows the detection of several RFBorrelia spp. found in Africa. These studies utilized gene targets for the most common RF Borrelia spp. in those regions: B. crocidurae, B. duttonii, B. recurrentis, and B. hispanica (117, 137).

TheglpQ gene is unique to RF Borrelia and therefore has been broadly used for NAAT. This gene discriminates between LB and RF Borrelia and is therefore very useful in diagnostic NAATs, especially in geographic areas where LB and RF Borrelia spp. coexist (75, 117). Within glpQ, there is a 4-bp single nucleotide polymorphism that is unique to B. crocidurae (137).

Studies investigatingB. miyamotoi infection in humans suggest the application of the same NAAT used for other RF Borrelia, for either confirming infection or identifying RF Borrelia species (5, 71, 74, 123, 139).

sect1.title: Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (LB Borrelia Group)
sect1.para: The diagnostic value of PCR varies depending on the clinical disease stage, sample type, and volume, which together determine the concentration of organism present, and on the PCR method used (112, 113). Currently, PCR-based molecular tests are employed mainly in research settings and in commercial or reference laboratories. In addition to direct detection in clinical samples such as skin, blood, CSF, and synovial fluid or tissue, PCR has been used for detection of Borrelia as well as other tick-borne pathogens in Ixodes ticks and, in some laboratories, for confirmation of B. burgdorferi sensu lato growth in culture medium (112, 133).

Primers used for PCR ofB. burgdorferi sensu lato include those targeting flaB, 16S rRNA, 23S rRNA, 5S-23S rRNA spacer, p66, recA, ospA, and oppA1 sequences (6, 112). The latter has been used to detect different genospecies of B. burgdorferi sensu lato on the basis of hybridization probes and differential melting temperature characteristics. B. mayonii was discovered with this method, since it had a melting temperature outside what was expected for B. burgdorferi (6). Borrelia genospecies has also been determined by other methods, such as analysis of PCR after gel electrophoresis, restriction of the 5S-23S rRNA intergenic spacer, sequencing of flaB, hbb, ospC, and other genes, MLST, and assessing molecular size after gel electrophoresis or whole-genome sequencing (140–142).

The sensitivity of PCR for detection ofB. burgdorferi sensu lato DNA in skin lesions is usually high, with a median 69% positivity for patients with EM and 76% for patients with ACA (112). A European study reported that PCR positivity correlated with EM size or associated systemic symptoms, such as headache and fatigue (143).

In general, the sensitivity of PCR for detection ofB. burgdorferi DNA in blood, plasma, or serum samples from patients with Lyme borreliosis is low (<20%), particularly with samples from patients presenting past the early disease stage, due to the lack or low level of spirochetemia (112). An analysis at the Mayo Clinic Laboratories of real-time PCR testing on 9,197 samples submitted between 2012 and 2014 demonstrated that the test was rarely contributory. In their experience, only 13 of 3,127 (0.4%) blood samples, 81 of 1,196 (6.7%) synovial fluids, and only 3 of 4,782 (0.06%) CSF samples tested positive by PCR (6). However, sensitivity cannot be extrapolated from testing performed at reference laboratories that receive samples from unselected patient populations. A follow-up study of 7,292 clinical samples submitted to Mayo Clinic laboratory for tick-borne pathogens PCR was conducted using a pan-Borrelia PCR followed by MLST at the Minnesota Health Department and CDC. They identified 44 (0.6%) samples positive for Borrelia sp., 25 positive for B. burgdorferi, 9 positive for B. mayonii, 8 positive for B. miyamotoi, and 2 positive for other RF Borrelia spp. (83). Interestingly, although samples were collected from 47 U.S. states, B. mayonii was found only in samples from patients from the Midwest (83).

PCR studies on clinically characterized patients are more contributory to the role of this diagnostic modality in diagnosis. PCR on plasma samples from 66 patients with clinical diagnosis of EM was found to be positive in 44.6% (133). In a study from Europe, PCR on blood samples of patients presenting with Lyme neuroborreliosis was positive in 11.9% (88). A rate of 62% positivity in PCR of plasma samples was achieved by extracting Borrelia DNA from 1.25 ml of EDTA-whole blood, followed by isothermal amplification of seven B. burgdorferi sensu lato targets, for patients with early Lyme borreliosis (144). PCR of CSF from well-characterized patient populations with a clinical diagnosis of Lyme neuroborreliosis in Europe yielded sensitivities between 10.7 and 19.4% (88, 145). The sensitivity of CSF PCR in U.S. patients with suspected Lyme neuroborreliosis has been lower than in the European experience. In one study, only 1 of 20 (5%) CSF samples collected from children meeting the criteria for Lyme meningitis had a positive PCR result (146).

In well-selected cases, PCR has been successful on joint fluid or tissues from patients with untreated Lyme arthritis. PCR has a median sensitivity of 78% and is more sensitive than culture for detection ofB. burgdorferi in synovial fluid specimens (112). Although there are few data on European Lyme arthritis, the identification of borreliae in synovium or synovial fluid in Europe demonstrates different Borrelia species as the causative agents. Nevertheless, although B. burgdorferi sensu stricto is not the predominant species causing Lyme borreliosis in Europe, it is a frequent etiology of Lyme arthritis. A French multicenter retrospective study including 52 patients with Lyme arthritis reported positive PCR results for 16 (39%) patients. B. burgdorferi sensu stricto and B. garinii were found in 5 patients (31.2%) each and B. afzelii in 3 (18.8%), while for 3 (18.8%) samples, the involved species was undetermined (147). Another French study of 37 patients with PCR-confirmed Lyme arthritis found B. burgdorferi sensu stricto in 19 (54%), B. afzelii in 10 (29%), and B. garinii in 6 (17%) patients (148).

sect1.title: Relapsing Fever Borrelia Group
sect1.para: Because RFBorrelia can be directly detected in clinical samples by the methods mentioned above during the recurrent febrile episodes, serological tests have limited utility for diagnosis of acute infections. These tests have been mainly useful in population studies and in confirming infection due to emerging species.

An indirect immunofluorescent antibody (IFA) assay using wholeB. recurrentis cell antigens has been used to detect IgG antibodies (76). This method suffers from lack of specificity and requires further confirmation by other more specific antibody detection methods, such as Western blotting.

Previously used IFA assays and enzyme immunoassays (EIA) containing whole-cell lysate of pure culture ofB. recurrentis or B. hermsii have been replaced with EIA using recombinant GlpQ antigen to detect antibodies (57, 149). This antigen, a 39-kDa protein, is present only in RF Borrelia spp.; therefore, this assay is specific for this group of Borrelia (149). Otherwise, IgM and/or IgG reactivity to whole-cell lysates must be confirmed with an immunoblot test using the GlpQ antigen.

Tests with specific recombinant antigens are not commercially available, but several research laboratories are performing them. An assay using a recombinant antigen derived fromglpQ of B. miyamotoi was used to detect antibodies to this organism in a group of patients presenting with fever after I. scapularis tick bites in the northeastern United States. Of 29 confirmed cases, 25 (86%) cases with B. miyamotoi developed antibodies to GlpQ recombinant antigen (150). Although antibody assays using the GlpQ antigen have been deemed specific to confirm RF infections, recent studies have questioned their specificity and have proposed searching for other antigens to be used in the serology of this organism (151).

Other antigens that are unique to RFBorrelia include a 57-kDa protein named Borrelia immunogenic protein A (BipA) and two antigens from VMPs, the small one (Vsp; 20 kDa) and the large one (Vlp; 37 kDa) (4, 46, 122, 152). These antigens were not found in the Lyme borreliosis Borrelia group of spirochetes and therefore can distinguish RF from LB but cannot discriminate within the RF Borrelia group. The combination of several antigens increases the sensitivity and specificity of tests compared to the use of a single antigen, mainly GlpQ (122).

Patients with RFBorrelia infections develop antibody responses against several borrelial antigens that can be reactive in B. burgdorferi EIAs, including the C6 antibody assay (150, 153). However, most serum samples from these patients do not fulfill the Western blot criteria used for detection of B. burgdorferi antibodies (see details later in this chapter) (57, 117, 150). Sera from patients diagnosed with STARI have been found to be negative in the C6 peptide EIA (154). Interpretation of serological tests is often complicated in regions where RF is endemic, because of the high background reactivity, but also in regions where LB is endemic, as B. miyamotoi may be present.

Western blot testing for RFBorrelia is performed at reference laboratories and the CDC (153). Reactivity to RF Borrelia can be confirmed by Western blotting by observing IgG and IgM reactions to GlpQ and other antigens.

sect1.title: Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (LB Borrelia Group)
sect1.para: Because of their fastidious nature and the paucity ofB. burgdorferi sensu lato organisms in clinical samples, the detection of antibodies in serum samples is the mainstay of laboratory diagnosis of Lyme borreliosis (112, 113). In recent years, significant improvements have been made in serological diagnostics by use of an extended spectrum of recombinant antigens, including VlsE, and new techniques such as line blotting and multiplex testing.

sect1.title: Antigens
sect1.para: B. burgdorferi sensu lato has several immunodominant antigens, which are used in diagnostic testing. These determinants play a role in dissemination, immune evasion, and elicitation of antibody responses in the host (155) (Table 3).

Most important surface-exposed lipoproteins (Osps) are encoded on plasmids, but some are encoded on the chromosome. OspC (23 kDa) is expressed on the surface of the organism after the tick has obtained a blood meal. OspC allows the dissemination ofB. burgdorferi sensu lato to the tick salivary glands and is upregulated during early disease (155). It is one of the most immunodominant and specific Borrelia antigens; antibodies appear early in disease (156). Other surface plasmid-encoded antigens include OspA (31 kDa), OspB (34 kDa), and OspD (28 kDa), each of which is involved in adherence of B. burgdorferi to tick midgut epithelium. Although specific, these antibodies arise slowly during infection and are not suitable for early diagnosis.

Besides OspC, one of the most immunogenic antigens is the chromosomally encoded flagellin (FlaB, 41 kDa). Flagellin is very cross-reactive with flagellar antigens of other motile bacteria. Although antibodies can be detected in very early infection, this approach suffers from nonspecificity due to cross-reactivity (157).

VlsE (about 35 kDa) is an important immunodominant antigen in early and late disease and is mostly expressed in mammalian hosts but not on cultured spirochetes (158–161). Antigenic variation of VlsE allows B. burgdorferi sensu lato to persist in its natural reservoir, facilitating efficient acquisition by the tick (155, 160). An invariable and highly immunogenic region of VlsE (C6) has been synthesized and used in antibody assays (158, 161). VlsE is one of the most specific Borrelia burgdorferi antigens and has high significance in LB serology.

BmpA (39 kDa), a chromosomally encoded protein, is highly immunogenic in early disease (162). P66, a chromosomally encoded protein of 66 kDa, is a porin-like protein that functions as an adhesin by binding to mammalian cell receptors (155). Decorin-binding protein A (DbpA; 17 kDa) allows Borrelia to interact with connective tissue. BBK32 (47 kDa) is also plasmid encoded and can bind to fibronectin (163, 164). BBK32, along with OspE and related proteins, is mostly expressed in vivo (155).

The complex antigenic composition ofB. burgdorferi sensu lato and differential expression of these antigens under various conditions and stages of the infection make the selection of antigenic preparations for serology quite challenging. The first antibody assays for serodiagnosis of Lyme borreliosis used high-passage-number B. burgdorferi that had lost plasmids encoding highly immunogenic antigens such as OspC (157). In Europe, the presence of different Lyme Borrelia species has further complicated test design (165). Subsequent antibody assays have used low-passage-number strains, mostly the B31 strain in the United States, and purified natural antigens, and some have added recombinant antigens of importance. As knowledge about antigen characteristics and antibody development has increased, there have been improvements in serologic tests. Recombinant and peptide antigens have been used in diagnostic tests in the United States and Europe and have significantly improved the performance of immunoassays (166–175).

sect1.title: Methods
sect1.para: Several methods have been used to detect antibodies toB. burgdorferi sensu lato, including the following: IFA assays; EIA, such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA); chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA); and immunoblotting (IB). The current recommendation in the United States is to use two-step testing, either standard two-tier testing (STTT), where IFA assay, ELISA, or CLIA is the first step, followed by Western blotting (WB) or IB as the second step for samples that are reactive in first-step testing (176), or modified two-tier testing (MTTT), where two EIAs are used sequentially (177). The two EIAs used in the MTTT should have different antigenic compositions, i.e., whole-cell antigens or recombinant/purified antigens. Although some research laboratories use in-house-developed tests, most testing performed for clinical use employs commercially available assays. Over 100 assays have been cleared by FDA in the United States since 1987, most using B. burgdorferi strain B31 as the source of antigens (178). There is no evidence to support the use of different Borrelia genospecies in serodiagnostic testing in Europe. In the case of whole-cell-lysate EIA, it is sufficient to use a single genospecies in the screening assay in Europe. The highest sensitivity is achieved with B. afzelii strain Pko (179). However, the U.S. immunoblot interpretation criteria (176) are not suitable for use in Europe.

sect1.title: Indirect Immunofluorescent Antibody Assay
sect1.para: The IFA assay was one of the first assays used in Lyme serology. It uses culturedBorrelia fixed onto glass slides. Serum specimens are diluted in preparations that may include an absorbent material, such as material derived from Treponema biotype Reiter or egg yolk sac, to block binding of nonspecific antibodies. After addition of fluorescein isothiocyanate-labeled anti-human IgG or IgM, the presence of Borrelia-specific antibodies is detected by fluorescence microscopy. Specimens reactive at the screening dilution are serially diluted. In general, antibody titers of ≥64 and ≥256 in IFA assays with and without prior absorption, respectively, are considered positive (180). Limitations of this assay include the need for fluorescence microscopy and well-trained personnel and the subjectivity in reading and interpreting fluorescence microscopy results. Although IFA assays are still commercially available, they have been largely replaced by EIA and CLIA.

sect1.title: Enzyme Immunoassays
sect1.para: The most common methods for detection of antibodies toB. burgdorferi sensu lato are ELISA (or other EIA) and CLIA (178, 181). The original commercially available or in-house assays using a whole-cell lysate of B. burgdorferi strain B31 as the source of antigen have been largely replaced by those using purified antigens, and, more recently, selected recombinant antigens (174, 178). Besides B31, other strains of B. burgdorferi are used in assays developed in the United States, while various LB Borrelia species and strains (B. burgdorferi, B. garinii, and B. afzelii) are employed in in-house or commercial assays available in Europe (182). ELISAs that detect IgM and IgG antibodies to B. burgdorferi antigens routinely include a low-positive control used to assess the reactivity of patient samples. Patient reactivity (optical density [OD]) is divided by the low-positive control and an index is calculated. Specific index values defined by the test manufacturer can be used to determine negative, equivocal, and positive results (178).

An EIA introduced over 15 years ago uses a synthetic peptide that reproduces invariable region 6 of the VlsE (C6) as the antigen (183). The C6 assay is FDA cleared for use in first-step testing (178), and it shows sensitivity similar to that of whole-cell EIA, 75% and 81.7%, respectively (184). The C6 assay also performs well as a second-step test, showing greater sensitivity than the standard two-tier testing (185, 186). Moreover, it has been investigated as a single-step test in the United States, showing marginally lower specificity than two-tier testing, 98.9% versus 99.5%, respectively (184). However, patients infected with B. miyamotoi can test positive in the C6 assay (150).

A commercial EIA that separately detects IgM antibodies to recombinant DbpA and OspC and IgG antibodies to VlsE, DbpA, and OspC was evaluated with the CDC serum panel (187). The authors compared the performance of this dissociated IgG and IgM ELISA versus combined IgG/IgM ELISA as first steps in the two-tier algorithm and found similar sensitivities (83% and 85%, respectively) and specificities (88% and 88%, respectively). The advantage of this assay includes the selection of the corresponding IB as a second tier, theoretically decreasing the number of IBs performed. In this study, the number of blots performed decreased by 27% (187).

Another commercial test that is widely applied as a primary test in Europe is a CLIA that separately detects IgM antibodies to recombinant OspC and VlsE and IgG antibodies to VlsE. Significant differences in sensitivity and specificity compared to a C6 assay were not observed; advantages of this assay is that it is automated and the first step can discriminate between IgM and IgG antibodies (175, 188).

The sensitivity of immunoassays depends on the duration of infection. The sensitivity (of ELISA and CLIA) is in general less than 50% in acute-phase sera of patients with EM with a duration of less than 1 week (189). Sensitivity of these assays increases after the first week for untreated patients with EM. Sensitivity is also high for samples from patients with EM presenting with constitutional signs and symptoms and those who have multiple EMs (189). Sensitivity is high for patients with objective evidence of extracutaneous involvement during early infection (e.g., carditis or Lyme neuroborreliosis). Immunoassays (ELISA and CLIA) are almost invariably positive in sera of patients with late disease manifestations, such as arthritis and ACA (187, 190, 191). A systematic literature review on the diagnostic accuracy of serological tests for Lyme borreliosis in Europe reported on the heterogeneity of available tests that limited the recommendations on their use in clinical practice. Nevertheless, as has been reported in the United States, the sensitivity of these tests increased according to duration of infection (175).

The Lyme borreliosis EIA has advantages over other immunoassays, including ease of testing, objective quantitative results that correlate in relative terms with the quantity of antibodies present, and the capability of automation. One of the limitations of EIA for detection ofB. burgdorferi sensu lato antibodies is lack of standardization. Variations exist between assays in terms of antigenic composition used by different manufacturers and in the detection of specific immunoglobulin classes, particularly in the detection of IgM antibodies. Variations can occur between lots of the same kit. One limitation of LB EIA tests is the lack of specificity due to the use of whole-cell antigen preparations. In Europe, there is now mandatory certification (CE marking) of the tests. However, this provides only minimum consistency and is not an overall guarantee of quality. Comprehensive demonstration of performance in multicenter studies is not yet required for certification. The specificity of EIA for detection of B. burgdorferi sensu lato antibodies is, in general, below 97% (184). Samples from patients with confirmed B. miyamotoi infection will also react in these assays; 90% of such cases seroconverted in an IgM EIA used by a reference laboratory, but only 10% met the two-tier testing criteria by IB (44). Similar findings were reported in a seroreactivity and seroprevalence study conducted in the northeastern United States (150).

sect1.title: Immunoblots
sect1.para: Detection of antibodies to different antigenic components ofB. burgdorferi has greatly contributed to the understanding of the immune response during different stages of the disease (162, 189, 192). Traditionally, Western blots (WB) contain whole-cell preparations of B. burgdorferi that are electrophoretically separated into proteins by size, after which they are transferred to membranes to be used as antigens. Recent modifications of the IB assays include the use of purified or recombinant borrelial antigens that are applied in well-defined positions on the strip (lines, spots, or bands) or as a microarray onto the membranes (193). The use of recombinant antigens in line IB reduces the background reactivity commonly observed with classic WB. For IB, diluted serum samples are reacted with membrane strips to detect IgG and IgM antibodies to the different antigenic components. Currently, there are few commercially available, FDA-approved IB kits in the United States (178). Some of these have the capability of densitometric reading to score bands of significance. Bands are scored visually by comparing the band intensity to that of control materials used as intensity controls. This approach is cumbersome and is prone to subjective interpretation, particularly for overreading of IgM IBs. Densitometric readings have been used to address this, but this approach has shown slightly lower sensitivity compared with visual scoring (187). The microarray IB is an automated assay and is performed using multiwell plates that contain a membrane at the bottom of each well with spotted antigens. These antigens are those recommended by CDC in the STTT criteria. Reaction intensity is read using a colorimetric imaging system; the automatic detection of multiple immunoreactive antigens performed simultaneously on numerous samples, with short turnaround time, reduces the labor cost and eliminates the need for manual handling and reading (193). This assay has not yet been cleared by the FDA for use in the United States.

sect2.title: STTT
sect2.para: Consensus on the criteria for using serology to support the diagnosis of Lyme borreliosis in the United States was achieved in 1994 during the second conference on standardization of LB testing (176). One of the organizers of this conference was the CDC, and the proposed criteria became known as the CDC criteria. According to the CDC criteria, samples should first be tested by a sensitive screening ELISA, CLIA, or IFA assay that detects IgG and IgM antibodies to B. burgdorferi, and reactive samples should be tested with separate IgG and IgM IB. A positive result in the IgM IB requires reactivity to at least two of three antigens (bands): 23 (OspC), 39, and 41 kDa (162). A positive result in the IgG IB requires reactivity to at least five of 10 antigens: 18, 23, 28, 30, 39, 41, 45, 58, 66, and 93 kDa (192) (Fig. 2). It was further recommended to use IgM IB only within the first 30 days of early disease (the 30-day rule) and to use IgG IB at any stage of the disease (176).

Similar to the CDC criteria, STTT was also introduced into many European laboratories, but few countries developed national guidelines (194). This is due to the availability of many different serological assays on the European market, differences in geographic seroprevalence of Lyme borreliosis, and laboratory/clinician experience in diagnosing Lyme borreliosis (175, 194, 195). European guidelines were first published in 1996 by the European Union Concerted Action on Lyme Borreliosis (EUCALB), updated in 2010, and reviewed in 2018 by the ESCMID Study Group for Lyme Borreliosis (ESGBOR) (96, 195, 196). These guidelines emphasize the appropriate use of testing to support the clinical diagnosis.

The STTT algorithm has low sensitivity in patients presenting with early disease such as EM, approximately 25 to 50% and 55 to 68% in the acute and convalescent phases, respectively (187, 189–191, 197) (Table 4). This is mostly due to the low sensitivity of the second-step IB, since almost half of samples from patients with early disease that are reactive by first-step testing do not fulfill the IB criteria. The limited sensitivity in early disease should not constitute a problem, since it is recommended that diagnosis at this stage be based on clinical findings. Nevertheless, modifications of two-tier testing are proposed to increase the sensitivity of serology in early disease (discussed below). The sensitivity of STTT is over 90% in early disseminated disease, except for samples tested after the 30-day cutoff with the IgM IB criteria. The sensitivity of STTT is close to 100% in late disease (187, 190, 198).

sect2.para: The specificity of the two-tier testing for Lyme borreliosis is over 98% (198). Caution should be used in areas where B. miyamotoi is prevalent, since about 10% of patients with this infection test positive in the two-tier approach used for Lyme borreliosis (44, 150). B. miyamotoi shares several antigens with B. burgdorferi sensu lato, including the 66-, 41-, and 39-kDa and heat shock proteins; therefore, sera from people infected with B. miyamotoi can react with several antigens in B. burgdorferi sensu lato IB. However, they might not reach the 5-band requirement for a positive IgG IB (150).

The serodiagnosis of Lyme borreliosis in Europe is more complex because of the presence of differentB. burgdorferi sensu lato genospecies causing disease in different geographic areas along with the large number of assays in use (199, 200). The European Union Concerted Action on Lyme Borreliosis promotes a two-tier testing protocol, but it is not used routinely in all European countries. The first step consists of an ELISA with a specificity of at least 90%, and the second step consists of an IB with a specificity of at least 95%. Some European assays use a whole-cell preparation including all B. burgdorferi sensu lato organisms that cause disease in Europe, with or without added recombinant antigens. Other assays use only recombinant antigens. IB interpretations vary according to manufacturer, and so the instructions for the specific kit should be consulted (201, 202). As per European experience, first-step tests that include selected recombinant antigens may be sufficient for confirming borrelial infection when correlating with clinical presentation, antibody development, and data on seroprevalence in a given geographic area (175, 195).

sect2.title: MTTT
sect2.para: Modifications to the two-tier testing protocols have been proposed in attempts to improve sensitivity in early disease and include the use of EIA rather than IB as a second step. The EIA included in both steps should be based on different antigen preparations (whole-cell versus purified or recombinant antigen). European authors first proposed the use of the C6 assay as a second-step EIA in Lyme borreliosis testing (185). Two-tier testing using the C6 assay as the second step has higher sensitivity than two-tier testing using IB as the second step in early Lyme borreliosis, while maintaining the high specificity of the STTT algorithm (186, 187, 191, 197) (Table 4). In 2019, the CDC published recommendations for LB serologic testing in the United States that included the use of the MTTT (177). Several commercial assays were then approved by the FDA to be used in MTTT algorithms (178).

The use of MTTT algorithms using combinations of EIA as the first and second steps has shown sensitivities and specificities similar to those of the previously described modified two-tier approaches (191). In this study, serum samples were tested by several two-EIA algorithms: whole-cell EIA was used as a first step, followed by a commercially available CLIA that uses full-length VlsE as the antigen or the C6 assay as a second step. The VlsE CLIA was also used as the first step, followed by the C6 assay. These modified two-tier algorithms have improved sensitivity in early Lyme borreliosis and specificities approaching that of the STTT (197, 198). Advantages of using MTTT include using assays that can be performed in routine clinical laboratories, decreasing the turnaround time to results, which is longer when IB needs submission to reference laboratories; in addition, it can be used to support the diagnosis of LB for patients acquiring the infection in Europe, since the second-step EIA is not specific to the Borrelia genospecies causing the infection. Another published modification of the STTT involved the use of an IgG IB that includes VlsE as one of the antigens in the blot interpretation (187, 190). With this modification, IgG reactivity to VlsE alone in the second step increased the sensitivity in early disease, including early disseminated disease. Compared with the STTT, this modification showed similar or higher specificity (Table 4). This approach has several advantages, including (i) avoiding the use of the IgM IB, which has interpretation challenges and can be used only during the first 30 days of infection; (ii) improved sensitivity in early disease, including early disseminated disease; (iii) retention of high sensitivity in late disease (191, 192), and (iv) the capability of visualizing reactivity to other significant antigens included in the IB. However, IB including VlsE has not been cleared by the FDA in the United States for patient testing.
